Message.Title: OPEN letter to MR. WIlliam GATES. PRESENT.
Message.Msg: Dear Mr. GATES: How are you Sir? Hope you are fine and thanks for all your philanthropic work, you set the example of what rich people should do. I want to propose to you this idea: The hardware wars are just starting, its the 1st inning of a full game, its the BIG PICTURE that matters here. When Apple came out with the iphone 1, iphone 2, 3, and 4 there was no WAR, but now with the Galaxy, WW1 of hardware has begun. MSFT has engaged the "Nook" but Mr. Gates, thats a very mild dab into the space. Dell is loaded with windows, its in every major corporation, together with your software. If MSFT wants to make a BOLD move, which it has not done in a LONG TIME, I propose to you Sir, consider an offer for the BEST IN CLASS windows hardware, by far and away, DELL. People like you make the phrase "Expect the Unexpected" true. Please surprise us Mr. Gates. Sincerely, "Miyamoto Musashi"

Topic.Title: Bing?

Message.Msg: you missunderstood what I wanted to say. Zuckerberg is basically looking to add a search engine to his facebook; this will stream more $$$$ for both companies (FB and whoever the search engine). However, Zuckerberg did not mention who FB would partner with-- could either be Google or Bing. Google made its name because of the search engine; hence, I imagine it would be much harder for Google to be flexible to FB's terms of negotiations. Thus, I think msft the fact that they have an awesome search engine but way under utilized because of lack of popularity and losing money, msft is more likely to strike a deal with FB. Hence, FB will likely get a cheaper deal with msft than with Google. Therefore, Msft will most likely get that joint venture with FB, rather than google.

Message.Title: Top Ten REasons to Buy MSFT
Message.Msg: 1) Laying dormant for 12 years, ready to explode 2) Windows 8 revolutionizes/hybridizes PC to touchpads 3) W8 sold 60 million copies in 10 weeks and counting. Priced at $69-99.00/copy, upgrades from other windows $39.99/copy. You do the math and estimates. 4) Surface (the first ever hybrid full functioning laptop and touchpad) and it only gets beter with next model the Surface Pro expected to be released in Jan 2013. 5) Trading just a buck from year's lowest, P/E ratio in low teens. 6) Windows phones are picking up steam (Nok lumnia and HTC) giving iphones and Sungsung's real competition. 7) Aapl is losing it's edge and funds are being transfered to msft 8) Most insititutional price targets are $31-35, BofA prices at $33; these guys almost never fail their price target. 9) The largest software company in the world, continual stream of income. Very low risk. 10) Needs Mobile internet access to become world dominance in tech: Surface with W8, allows a fully functional PC/laptop capability and touchscreen, With mobile internet access, you would have a machine that does everything: work, play, internet acess, mobile, print, and even phone.

Topic.Title: Bing?

Message.Msg: I may have misunderstood much more than what you wanted to say. \-: I thought Bing was already the search engine FB is using. And what I keep seeing on the web are comments saying that FB is trying to compete with Google in search. Certainly they could compete as partners but I wasn't seeing it that way based on what I read. But there doesn't seem to be any announcement yet and it's also not impossible that FB could be rolling out their own search facility. So for now all I can do is wait to see what really happens.

Topic.Title: Top Ten REasons to Buy MSFT

Message.Msg: 11) Bing, almost completely forgot. Joint venture with FB exposes Bing to much publicity and incomes. If anyone has ever used Bing, you would realize it has more contents than Google. Its ONLY downside is lack in popularity-- it's difficult to compete with Google search egnine that has become a "verb" in our culture, but FB exposure may just do it for msft in this arena. Even if I wanted to use Bing, I still accidently type Google in the address bar--- old habit is hard to break.

Topic.Title: why doesn't anybody ever discuss the core issue.

Message.Msg: ""The Feds passed an increase in the minimum wage that had little effect, since the market rate minimum wage (for all employers) was higher than that. The facts were, if an employer wasn't offering $8 or $9 per hour they would have trouble attracting new employees."" I would like to see a source on this. And it is inadequate analysis to assume that the fed min wage floor does not affect wages paid above this floor. If abolished some would no doubt see their pay drop and this would put downward pressure on those making above min. Yes business has clients to serve and need a labor force but this not eliminate the possibility of a slow downward trend in wages if min wage laws were canceled. Companies are reluctant to commit cash because they don't believe markets exist mainly due to the greatly decreased purchasing power of the middle class. The rest is not relevant. Remember the question or challenge was to support a concept of what the steady state situation of the poor would be without progressive measures.

He applied the presidential power to withhold documents a House committee is seeking in an investigation of a flawed gun-smuggling probe called Operation Fast and Furious. The White House says presidents have asserted that privilege 25 times since 1980. Message.Title: People With Guns In Home At Greater Risk!!
Message.Msg: Those persons with guns in the home were at greater risk than those without guns in the home of dying from a homicide in the home (adjusted odds ratio = 1.9, 95% confidence interval: 1.1, 3.4). They were also at greater risk of dying from a firearm homicide, but risk varied by age and whether the person was living with others at the time of death. The risk of dying from a suicide in the home was greater for males in homes with guns than for males without guns in the home (adjusted odds ratio = 10.4, 95% confidence interval: 5.8, 18.9). Persons with guns in the home were also more likely to have died from suicide committed with a firearm than from one committed by using a different method (adjusted odds ratio = 31.1, 95% confidence interval: 19.5, 49.6). Results show that regardless of storage practice, type of gun, or number of firearms in the home, having a gun in the home was associated with an increased risk of firearm homicide and firearm suicide in the home.

Message.Title: OT: NASA driven by politics, not science
Message.Msg: From time to time on this board, an item originating with NASA is cited, as if NASA were an unbiased source of scientific data, especially on the topic of anthropogenic global warming. The story of the Challenger disaster refutes that view. I was viewing some videos on YouTube, for purposes of my own, pertaining to Richard Feynman, an actual scientist, one of the most brilliant who ever lived -- and never a NASA employee. An episode late in Feynman's life did involve NASA, however. In the aftermath of the Challenger disaster in 1986, Feynman was recruited as part of the blue-ribbon panel to investigate the cause of the disaster. As Feynman told the story afterward, he was "played" by someone inside NASA, who hinted to him, at his own home, as if by accident, what the cause might have been -- O-ring seals malfunctioning at low temperatures. The NASA employee knew what the cause had been, but also knew that if he said what he knew publicly, he would be fired, as another employee had already been fired for that reason. To make the cause known, it was necessary to go by way of someone outside NASA, not an employee, someone with unchallengeable credentials as a scientist, therefore someone who could not be silenced and would be believed. NASA management had been informed of the O-ring problem BEFORE the mission launch by its own engineers. NASA management ignored its own engineers and sent the crew to their deaths, for political reasons. And then they tried to cover it up afterwards. NASA's committee chairman attempted to delete Feynman's contribution from the committee report, and any other reference to the O-ring problem, but Feynman threatened not to sign the report unless it was included. What was eventually included was much watered down. So much for scientific objectivity at NASA.

OT: NASA driven by politics, not science

Message.Msg: The Challenger matter was not the last of its kind. There was also the launch of the Hubble space telescope. Once it was in space, it turned out that no one had tested it on the ground, to see whether it was capable of taking pictures in focus. And in fact it was not. An unbelievable screwup. The subsequent mission to put it right is an amazing story in itself, but doesn't erase the mismanagement that made it necessary.

Message.Title: U.S. Industrial Production Rises 0.3% on Equipment Demand
Message.Msg: U.S. Industrial Production Rises 0.3% on Equipment Demand Production at U.S. factories climbed more than forecast in December and the cost of living was little changed, showing the economy gained momentum entering 2013 while inflation remained at bay. Manufacturing output advanced 0.8 percent after jumping 1.3 percent in November, the strongest back-to-back reading in almost a year, Federal Reserve figures showed today. The Labor Department said its consumer-price index was unchanged last month, capping the third-smallest annual gain in a decade.

Topic.Title: NASA Is About Science, Tea Party Republicans Grover Norquist Koch Bros is about politics

Message.Msg: Successor agency to the prior National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics subsuming its roles and resources and expanding on them in part for the "preservation of the role of the United States as a leader in aeronautical and space science and technology". The enabling law and underlying rationales are codified as the "National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958". Acts of Congress are by definition expressions of the will pf the People through their representatives.
